Name: Is non-agreement in number between the nominal subject and verbal predicate possible?
Are there nonfinite forms that can be used both as participles and action nominalizations?
Can modifiers of action nominalization in agent and patient roles both be marked like possessors?
Is there morphologically conditioned stress?
Is there a distinct category of dual for verbal agreement with a dual subject?
Can finite verbs agree in number with the nominal object?
Comment: The number of the object is indexed on the verb, e.g. 1SG meə-w° (singular object), 1SG meŋa-xəyu-n° (dual object), 1SG me-yə-n° (plural object); me- ‘to take, to do’ (Nikolaeva 2014: 79).

Name: Can an adnominal property word agree with the noun in case?
Comment: Still, number concord is more common (Nikolaeva 2014: 151).

Name: Are there cases that do not show agreement in terms of case?
Can adpositions be used to mark core verbal arguments?
Can adpositions be used to mark non-core/oblique verbal arguments?
Example: mənʹ tol°-h ŋil°na meə-d°m;I table-GEN under be-1SG;I am under the table;Nikolaeva 2014: 263

Name: Can non-finite clauses entail a special way for a core argument (S/A) marking?
Example: [nʹabako-nʹi xǣ-qmʹa-xəd°] xoneyə-w°q;elder.sister-GEN.1SG go-PERF.AN-ABL go.to.sleep-REFL.1SG;When my sister left, I went to sleep;Nikolaeva 2014: 287
Comment: In different-subject sentences, the lexical dependent subject is marked with the genitive (Nikolaeva 2014: 287).

Name: Can non-finite clauses entail a special way for a core argument (P) marking?
Comment: The object of transitive verbs is marked with the accusative both in finite as well as non-finite clauses (Nikolaeva 2014: 61).

Name: Do characteristics of object referent (topicality, animacy, definiteness) influence object marking?
Does object marking correlate with aspectuality?
Does the marking of the object depend on the verb conjugation form?
Example: pisʹmo / pisʹmo-m tola-q;letter / letter-ACC read-IMP.2SG;Read the/a letter!;Nikolaeva 2014: 202
Comment: Objects are typically marked with the accusative case. However, in the imperative also the nominative case is possible (Nikolaeva 2014: 202).

Name: Is there differential subject marking?
Can S and A be conflated morphologically across clause boundaries, i.e. act as syntactic pivot?
Can S and P be conflated morphologically across clause boundaries, i.e. act as syntactic pivot?
Is there a grammatical device for habituality?
Is there a grammatical device for frequentative?
Example:
ladə > lador-;;to hit : to hit many times;Nikolaeva 2014: 512|ŋox°lə- > ŋox°lʹur-;;to swim > to swim here and there, to swim
habitually;Nikolaeva 2014: 512
Comment: There are the frequentatie-iterative-multiplicative suffixes -or, -ur, -er indicating that a situation is repeated, habitual or dispersive (Nikolaeva 2014: 512).

Name: Is there a grammatical device for progressivity?
Is it common to use a verb in the present tense for future time reference?
Is there a grammatical device for immediate future?
Comment: The future tense conveys both immediate as well as remote future (Nikolaeva 2014: 83).

Name: Is there a grammatical device for pluperfect?
Example: xǣ-wa-nt° nʹer°cʹuna wərk°-m xada°-wa-cʹ°;go-IMPF.AN-GEN.2SG before bear-ACC kill-1PL-PAST;We had killed a bear shortly before you left; Nikolaeva 2014: 82 (T 304)
Comment: Whereas imperfective verbs typically have progressive reading, the perfective verbs usually indicate remote past. In addition, a perfective verb may be used to denote an event, which occurred before another event in the past (Nikolaeva 2014: 81-82).

Name: Can aspect be expressed overtly on the negative marker?
Comment: Aspectual morphology is expressed on the lexical verb (Nikolaeva 2014: 273).

Name: Can tense be expressed overtly on the negative marker?
Example: ŋaw°na wǣwa-h yilʹeə-cʹ°;in.the.past bad-GEN live-3PL.PAST;In the past they lived poorly;Nikolaeva 2014: 81 (T 66)

Name: Is there grammatical marking of mirativity?
Comment: "The inferential evidential also has a mirative or exclamative use" (Nikolaeva 2014: 95).

Name: Is there morphological marking on the verb dedicated to the expression of desire or wish?
Is there morphological marking for irrealis (e.g. hypothetical state of affairs)?
Are verbs marked in a specific mood in counterfactual conditional clauses?
Is there morphological marking on the verb dedicated to the expression of deontic necessity?
Is there morphological marking on the verb dedicated to the expression of epistemic possibility?
Example: xuna-rʹi ŋǣ°-ya, sʹax°rʹih xo-bcaki°-q;DP-LIM be-JUS then.LIM find-POT-REFL.3SG;Wherever he is, he will probably be found one day;Nikolaeva 2014: 91 (T 781)

Name: Is there morphological marking on the verb dedicated to the expression of deontic possibility?
Is there morphological marking on the verb used to express indirect commands/wishes etc. directed to the 3Sg?
Example: tʹuku° kniga-m temtaə-ya;this book-ACC buy-JUS;Let him buy this book;Nikolaeva 2014: 269

Name: Is there morphological marking on the verb used to express indirect commands/wishes etc. directed to the 1Sg?
Example: mənʹ° tʹuku°-cʹey°-m xana-xə-d°m;I this-EMPH-ACC take-HORT-1SG;Let me take this away;Nikolaeva 2014: 86 (T 696)
Comment: The horative is used to express exhortations to the first person; it appears in 1SG, 1DU and 1PL.

Name: Is it common to use the imperative/jussive in complement clauses introduced by predicates expressing wish/desire/will?
Is there morphological marking on the verb dedicated to the expression of apprehension?
Example: yer°mpoy°  nʹū-mʹi  ŋanʹih  nʹi-r°wa-q xaŋkul°-q!;INTRJ child-1SG again NEG-APPR-REFL.3SG get.ill-CONNEG;If only my child wouldn’t get ill!;Nikolaeva 2014: 90

Name: Is there reflexive conjugation?
Comment: The reflexive conjugation is formed based on the reflexive stem (Nikolaeva 2014: 78-79).

Name: Are there syntactically ditransitive verbs?
Can non-singular 2nd and 3rd person have the same person/number marking or morphosyntactic treatment?
Can an impersonal (or passive) form be used instead of a finite plural form with an overt subject expression?
Can third person plural verb forms be used for impersonal reference?
Example: tʹukoxəna yedey° mʹad°-m sʹerta-bʹiq;here new tent-ACC do-DUR.3PL;A new tent is being built here;Nikolaeva 2014: 200

Name: Can second person singular verb forms be used in generic meaning?
Are clauses with only infinitive predicates possible?
Can verbs in purposive subordinate clauses be in bare infinitive form?
Example: nʹa-xənta xǣ-wəncʹ° ŋəno-də-nta sʹertaə-sʹ°;companion-DAT.3SG go-PURP boat-PRED-GEN.3SG do-PAST;He made a boat in order to visit his younger brother;Nikolaeva 2014: 382
Comment: There is the purposive converb (final gerund).

Name: Are there sentences without overt verbal arguments (e.g. weather verbs)?
Example: (num-ta) məlʹe° təlmə°?;sky-3SG already get.dark;Has it got dark already;Nikolaeva 2014: 228|сарёбтылы̄”;;There was a light rain;
Comment: The subject (god/sky/wheather) can be omitted although it is more common to express the subject (Nikolaeva 2014: 228).

Name: Is copula needed for predicate nominals in the 3rd person form of the present tense?
Is a copula needed for predicate nominals in the past and/or future tense?
Example: wǣwa-d°m / wǣwa ŋǣ-ŋku-d°m;bad-1SG / bad be-FUT-1SG;I will be bad;Nikolaeva 2014: 252
Comment: The copula is not needed for the past tense, but it is needed for the future tense (Nikolaeva 2014: 252).

Name: Can locative adverbial phrases act as predicates without a copula?
Example: wenʹako mʹa-k°na me°;dog tent-LOC be;The dog is in the tent;Nikolaeva 2014: 263

Name: Can the same coordinating conjunction be used for NPs, VPs, and clauses?
Example: Coordinating conjunctions can be found but this is not the commonest coordination strategy (see Nikolaeva 2014: 414-417).

Name: Does existential negation have a separate operator?
Example: mʹa-k°wa-da tənʹa°, ŋəno-da yəŋku;tent-AFF-3SG exist boat-3SG no;He does have a tent, he doesn’t have a boat;
Comment: There are two existential copulas: tənʹa° (affirmative) and yəŋku (negative) (Nikolaeva 2014: 250). Cf. standard negation: pida nʹī məncara-q (he NEG work-CONNEG) 'He did not work / he is not working' (Nikolaeva 2014: 260).

Name: Can standard negation be asymmetric in the present tense?
Example: tʹanʹo-xərt° tudako-m nʹī-dəm xo-q;little-FOC mushroom-ACC NEG-1SG find-CONNEG;I don’t even find a few mushrooms;Nikolaeva 2014: 128

Name: Can non-finite dependent clauses use the standard negation construction?
Example: wada-m nʹi-sʹ° mes°-q xǣ-wi°;word-ACC NEG-MOD use-CONNEG leave-INFR;He left without saying a word;Nikolaeva 2014: 305
Comment: Modal, purposive, and conditional coverbs can be negated like finite verbs (Nikolaeva 2014: 305).

Name: Is there a special negator that combines with non-finite forms?
Comment: For instance, n'iwa negates action nominals (Nikolaeva 2014: 304).

Name: Are there special negative non-finite forms?
Example: lador-mədawey°;hit-NEG.PART;the one who did not hit;Nikolaeva 2014: 107

Name: Is there an impersonal passive construction?
Comment: Only transitive verbs are passivized.

Name: Are there nonfinite forms specialized on the relativization of particular core participants, e.g. subjects (S/A), direct objects (P), absolutive participants (S/P)?
Are there nonfinite forms that can relativize at least all core participants (S/A/P) and possibly also some noncore participants, e.g. locative adverbials, instruments, etc.?
Are there nonfinite forms that can relativize at least some noncore participants, e.g. locative adverbials or instruments, but cannot relativize all or some of the core participants, e.g. subjects?
Is there a specialized negative participial form, which cannot be analyzed as a specific participial marker + negation marker?
Example: xada-wədawey°;kill-NEG.PART;the one who did not kill;Nikolaeva 2014: 107

Name: Is there a future participle?
Example: nū-sʹ° meq-m°nta pʹa-mʹi;stand-MOD use-FUT.PART tree-1SG;the tree on which I will stand;Nikolaeva 2014: 320

Name: Are there participles that can encode their subject by possessive suffixes?
Example: [wol°tampə-wemt°] xoba-mt°;dislike-PERF.PART.ACC.2SG skin-ACC.2SG;the skin (ACC) that you disliked;Nikolaeva 2014: 315
Comment: When agreeing with the head noun, participles can take possessive suffixes.

Name: Can subject in at least some participial subordinate clauses be encoded in the same way as in independent clauses?
Example: [xūbta-xəna nʹabako-mʹi mənc°ra-qma-xəd°nta] yalʹa-h xoni;morning-LOC elder.sister-1SG work-PERF.AN-ABL.3SG day-GEN sleep.REFL.3SG;After my sister works in the morning, she sleeps in the day time;Nikolaeva 2014: 286
Comment: "In same-subject sentences the dependent subject stands in the nominative form if it is overt and triggers person/number marker of the possessive type" (Nikolaeva 2014: 286).

Name: Are there participles that obligatorily agree with the nouns they modify in case and number (in all contexts)?
Comment: See UT060.

Name: Are there nonfinite forms that can be used both as participles and agentive nominalizations?
Comment: There is no special agentive nominalization form, present participles are used regularly as agentive nominalizations.

Name: Are there nonfinite forms that can be used both as participles and converbs without any additional morphological material, such as case markers?
Example: yil’e-s’° m’aq-m’i;live-CVB.MOD tent-1SG;the tent in which I live;Nikolaeva 2014: 322|[ŋarka pæ-n°h t’ebə-°] xən° wabtarey°-q;big stone-DAT bump.into-CVB.MOD sledge turn.over-REFL.3SG;The sledge turned over after/because it bumped into a big stone;Nikolaeva 2014: 378

Name: Is OV the neutral order in affirmative imperative clauses?
Example: ti / ti-m xada-q;reindeer / reindeer-ACC kill-IMP.2SG;Kill a reindeer;Nikolaeva 2014: 60

Name: Is it possible to place an object between the negative marker and the main verb in imperative constructions?
Are there preverbs?
Are there verbal prefixes?
Is there diminutive (hypocoristic) marking on verbs?
Comment: The diminutive marking on verbs expresses the meaning 'for some time, for a while' (Nikolaeva 2014: 46).

Name: Can the modifier of action nominalization in patient role (e.g. "drinking of coffee") be marked like the direct object?
Do core adjectives agree with the subject noun in number in the predicative position?
Example: tʹuku° wenʹako-x°h səwa-x°h;this dog-3DU good-3DU;These two dogs are/were good;Nikolaeva 2014: 252

Name: Is it possible to form synthetic superlative?
Comment: There is no synthetic superlative. Superlatives are formed with the help of adverbs expressing 'very', 'most', e.g. s'am'anəxət° 'most' (Nikolaeva 2014: 176).

Name: Can adpositions have person/number marking?
Comment: Pronominal object can be marked in the postposition, e.g. ŋil°mna-ntoh ‘along the place under them (3PL)' (Nikolaeva 2014: 51).

Name: Are there separate adpositions to express goal, source, and location (without there being syncretism)?
Comment: Local postpositions usually appear in the locative (n´ana 'at'), dative (nʹah  'to'), (ablative nʹad° 'from') and prolative form (nʹamna 'along')  (Nikolaeva 2014: 51).

Name: Is case compounding possible?
Are there case categories only found in pronouns?
Does the numeral modification of a noun have an effect on its case selection?
Is the singular form of the noun also used with numerals bigger than 1?
Comment:
With numerals the quantified noun can stand in the singular or plural. In Tereshchenko (1965), it is usually in the singular. However, the speakers of the modern language prefer the plural, though may accept
the singular as well. (Nikolaeva 2014: 162)

Name: Is there a genitive case that has an affix?
Is there a dative case used to express indirect object/receiver/goal (different from a local case)?
Comment: The dative case also expresses lative meanings.

Name: Is there a terminative case?
Is there a separate case to indicate without what/who an action takes place / does not take place?
Comment: There is a caritive adverbial form that ends in -s'iq. (Nikolaeva 2014: 38).

Name: Is there a separate case to mark the motion along or by the referent of the noun (prolative)?
Is there a locative case that marks goal?
Example: lam°pa-n°h xərasʹin°-m xəmta-q;lamp-DAT kerosene-ACC pour-IMP.2SG;Pour some kerosene into the lamp;Nikolaeva 2014: 62
Comment: The dative case (-n°h ~ -t°h) is used; it is regarded as a local case.

Name: Is there a locative case that marks location?
Comment: There is the locative case, which additionally expresses instrumental and comitative meanings, means of transportation as well as cause.

Name: Is there a locative case that marks source?
Is there case syncretism of goal and location marking?
Is there case syncretism of location and source marking?
Are there two sets of local cases?
Is there a third set of local cases?
Is there a separate case for marking the means by which something is carried out (instrumental) and/or accompaniement (comitative)?
Comment: The Locative case may be used in both functions.

Name: Is there a separate case for marking accompaniment, which is different from the instrumental?
Is there a separate case for marking the result of change (translative) and/or a state of being (essive)?
Comment: The derivational suffix -ngæ appears in a similar function, e.g. li 'bone', lingæ 'as a bone, for a bone'.

Name: Is there a separate case for marking the state of being (essive), which is different from the translative?
Is there a separate morphological marker for expressing equative meaning?
Comment: However, there is an adverbial form marked by the suffix -(də)r'em (Nikolaeva 2014: 39).

Name: Is there an inflectional nominal marker for expressing benefactive or destinative semantics independent from the dative?
Example: yid°-h warə-n°h ŋəno-də-mʹi to°;water-GEN edge-DAT boat-PRED-1SG come;A boat for me came to the shore;Nikolaeva 2014: 73
Comment: The predistinative is used (Nikolaeva 2014: 72).

Name: Is there in addition to the basic declension a declension different from a possessive declension?
Is it possible to use singular with paired body parts/clothing/accessories that accompany them?
Comment: Paired objects typically stand in plural (Tereschenko 1956: 40), still, dual may be encountered as well - 'my eyes’ can be expressed either as sǣw°-xəyu-nʹi (DU) or as sǣw°-nʹi (PL) (Nikolaeva 2014: 59).

Name: Can the marking of the possessor in the attributive construction vary?
Example: noxa-h tǣwa;olar.fox-GEN tail;polar fox's tail;Nikolaeva 2014: 142|(pida) puxac'a-da;he wife-3SG;his wife;Nikolaeva 2014: 143
Comment: Whereas the lexical possessor takes the genitive form, the pronominal possessor appears in the nominative form.

Name: Can the possessor in the attributive construction be marked with the nominative?
Comment: Pronominal possessor appears in the nominative form (Nikolaeva 2014: 142).

Name: Is non-singular possession marked in the possessive declension?
Can 2Sg possessive suffix be used to mark definiteness?
Example: puxacʹa-ko yilʹe-wi°. puxacʹa-ko-nt° sʹidʹa səwa nʹu-da;old.woman-DIM live-INFR old.woman-DIM-GEN.2SG 2 good child-3SG;An old woman lived. This old woman had two nice sons;Nikolaeva 2014: 69

Name: Can 3Sg possessive suffix be used to mark definiteness?
Example: tʹukona sira(-da) wər-cawey°;here snow-3SG dirt-PROP;The snow is dirty here;Nikolaeva 2014: 69
Comment:
"[T]he 3rd person singular possessive affixes express identifiability based on deixis and situational
context" (Nikolaeva 2014: 68). Their usage in this function is, however, optional.

Name: Is there animacy distinction in independent interrogative pronouns?
When used as a relative pronoun, is it common to use 'who' for animates other than humans?
When used as a relative pronoun, is it common to use 'who' for inanimates?
Can a demonstrative stem be used in the function of a pronoun with 3rd person singular human referent?
Is the order of possessive suffix and case suffix across the paradigm the same?
Comment: case + Px

Name: Is the order of number and case suffixes fixed across the paradigm the same?
Comment: number + case

Name: Are there different words for mother’s brother and father’s brother?
Are there different words for younger and older relative for other relations than siblings?
Example: нея;;mother’s younger sister;|хада;;mother’s older sister, father’s older sister;|тидя;;mother’s younger brother;

Name: Is there animacy distinction for both concepts 'new/young' and 'old'?
Is there distinction for both 'warm' and 'cold' based on whether referring to weather or to temperature of objects?
Example: епика, иба, лимбада, хольмёй - тецьда, япда - translations?

Name: Is there contrastive length of consonants?
Is there contrastive length of vowels?
Comment: pud 'something giving balace' vs. púd 'from behind; after'

Name: Is there contrast between short and long unstressed vowels?
Is there contrast in duration of geminate consonants?
Are there more than two phonological quantities?
Are there extralong syllables?
Is the main foot structure trochaic?
Comment: Tundra Nenets exhibits bisyllabic trochaic feet aligned to the left. (Nikolaeva 2014:28)

Name: Is there lexically distinctive word stress?
Comment: yábta 'thin' vs. yabtá 'dew'

Name: Is there fixed primary stress?
Comment: Stress is predictable from syllable and segmental structure. It falls on an initial syllable, syllables preceding a syllable with schwa, and non-final syllables precided by am unstressed syllable. (Salminen 1998: 519)

Name: Is there stress in heavy syllables?
Is there non-initial primary stress?
Is there palatal vowel harmony?
Is there velar vowel harmony?
Is there labial vowel harmony?
Are there rising diphthongs?
Are there lowering diphthongs?
Is there qualitative contrast between subsets of short and long vowels?
Are there full vs. reduced vowels as contrastive subsets?
Is there front high rounded vowel ü [y]?
Is there front midhigh rounded vowel ö [ø]?
Is there back high unrounded vowel ï [ɯ]?
Is there back midhigh unrounded vowel ë [ɤ]?
Comment: There is only allophonic ɤ (Salminen 1997; Nikolaeva 2014: 18).

Name: Is there back low round vowel [ɒ]?
Is there contrast between low and mid front vowels (ä [æ] vs. e [e])?
Are there word-initial consonant clusters?
Are there word-internal consonant clusters in syllable onset?
Are there consonant clusters in syllable coda?
Comment: xarw 'larch', sampønorcʲ 'to talk with the souls of dead'

Name: Are there clusters of three or more consonants in a word between vowels?
Are there word-final clusters of three or more consonants?
Are there palatalized dentals?
Comment: nʲaxør 'three' vs naxør 'nut'; tʲ vs t, lʲ vs l

Name: Are there palatalized labials and velars?
Comment: pʲa 'tree', mʲaʔ 'conical tent of reindeer hide'

Name: Is there palatal stop [c]?
Is there palatal nasal [ɲ]?
Is there palatal lateral [ʎ]?
Is there phonemic velar nasal [ŋ]?
Is there dental affricate [t͡s]?
Is there non-alveolar affricate (e.g. [t͡ʃ], [͡cɕ])?
Is there a phonological contrast between [s] and postalveolar sibilant [ʃ]?
Are there voiced plosives [b, g, d]?
Is there glottal stop [ˀ]?
Comment: See also Janhunen (1986).

Name: Is there phonological contrast between plain and labial velar consonants (e.g. [k] vs. [kʷ])?
Is there a constraint on word-initial r?
Comment: In literary language there are some loanwords beginning with r but there are no inherited stems beginning with r. In Russian loans beginning with r-, xa- or ng- may be pronounced in some dialects (e.g. risuida-> xarisuida- (< рисовать), ngrajonnoj (< районный). In older loanwords r- may be replaced by l-.

Name: Is there laryngeal fricative [h]?
Is there voiced velar fricative [ɣ]?
Is there voiceless velar fricative [x]?
Is there voiced dental fricative [ð]?
Is there phonemic labio-velar approximant [w]?
Is there voiceless labiodental fricative [f]?
Is there radical qualitative consonant gradation?
Is there quantitative consonant gradation?
